Fields.DialogueText: Proud of your new tools?
Kapitan, keep an eye on these duraki in sailors' clothing. I suspect they've been spoiled by my equipment.
Spoiled? You've practically been held together by ropes and gum since the war began.
Exactly! Why should the crew keep me in working order if I'm already not working?
That's the spirit. A well-maintained ship builds pride in one's duties.
Pah. So close, and yet so far. If I'm inches from capsizing, these layabouts are looking for escape routes with one eye.

Fields.MenuText: Well, now you're not. It should be smooth sailing from here.
Preposterous. Nobody could escape from you.
I think your crew are more responsible than that.

Fields.DialogueText: Better not be too smooth. I won't have anyone getting lazy.
You least of all. I've made sure of it.
I certainly wouldn't stick around if I thought it would kill me.
The Fleet doesn't tend to advertise that way, you know.
If they want to be in the sugarcoating business, they should be sending me sweets every time we make port.
If I'm going down, everyone's going with me.
Hey! Careful with that, I just had her installed!
Gee, if it counters the sourness...
What was that!?
*ALARM*
I said we've encountered a dour mess. Shall we show them the new and improved Gnevny?
Hmph. Nice try, Kapitan, but you could never be anywhere near as nasty as those Rusalki.
I'll take that as a compliment.
Good! Makes my job easier.
@BATTLE
Gnevny? Where are... ah. I think I've found her.
Gah! One more step and I'll...
You'll...?
Heh... not kill you? Chert poberi, Kapitan, but you really should announce yourself.
You know my voice.
If you're trying to stay ahead of the enemy, you might start by not leaving a trail of ashes wherever you go.
Blame the sailors! It's their fault if my decks aren't pristine.

Fields.MenuText: Routine maintenance is one thing. Cleaning up after your messes is another.
Am I going to have to crack down on your smoking?
You know you can tell me if there is anything wrong, right, Gnevny?

Fields.DialogueText: Shut up, Kapitan! I haven't done anything for you to be hounding me like this. The sailors know what they signed up for.
I can stop any time I want, Kapitan, and I sure as hell don't want to. Trust me, you don't want me to either.
Why would anything be wrong? I've never met a problem I can't grind into powder.
*ALARM*
See, Gnevny? Wishes do come true.
@BATTLE
Yep. Gnevny!
Well, it could be someone impersonating you. You can never be sure on the battlefield.
Come on, something's clearly on your mind.
... I just wish something would happen. It's such a pain waiting around for Rusalki. Sometimes I think our lookout's slacking.
I'm sure you'd be the first to find some if you kept watch more often. You're a Belle, after all. You can see them coming better than we can.
Da. I can see, all right. If nothing's happening, clearly I've got to make it happen. This isn't Scarlet Sails.
So they do. Our lookout lives another day.
Damn it! It's not like us to be caught napping.
Out of my way, sailor! They're right on top of us!
Whoa! Gnevny, what the hell? You almost knocked Ensign Palmgren overboard!
I don't see what the problem is. He was in my way.
The problem is that you nearly drowned one of your own sailors.
Well, that's what he gets if he insists on being an obstacle!

Fields.MenuText: You're smaller than he is. You could have dodged him.
You're the one who said I should announce myself. Why can't you?
You're a Belle. Can't you just appear where you're needed?

Fields.DialogueText: Aboard my own ship? They should be giving me the right of way!
There's a pecking order out here, Kapitan! Our war effort depends on it.
That's... I mean... Well, he's a lummox!
Ideally neither, but that's where we stand.
Otlichno. But don't blame me the next time I can't see my target.
That's no excuse to push people around. Apologize to him or I'm cutting off your cigarettes.
You're all right, sailor. Get to your station. I'll give her a talking to.
Thank me later! Nobody keeps me from my kill!
@BATTLE
Grr... You're making me choose which of my wrists to shackle.
*BOOM*
You two seem to be getting along.
Hmm? Oh, right. I suppose so.
You suppose so?
I went to him just like you told me, Kapitan. That look in his eyes was so pathetic...
Gnevny, I swear--
Molchi! Let me finish. I couldn't beat him into the deck like I was tempted to. He clearly knew his place. So I was magnanimous and acknowledged that he couldn't possibly have dodged me.

Fields.MenuText: That's not much of an apology.
I guess that's the best I'm going to get out of you.
You're really something, you know that?

Fields.DialogueText: The minute one is owed, I'll make the most sincere one you ever saw.
You will get nothing less out of me!
As long as everyone knows it, we'll get along just fine!
Anyway, he brightened up once I let him fire my mine gun.
That's a relief. What I really wanted to talk to you about was our next destination.
@BATTLE
Excellent shot, Ensign! We might make a gunner of you yet. Now back to your station.
I'm surprised you let him touch anything you own.
It can't break. And I thought he deserved to know what it was like to be me.
He must have appreciated the perspective.
I don't just hand it out. We understand each other much better now.
*ALARM*
Later, Kapitan. I'm off to go share my perspective with some Rusalki.
Feast your eyes, Gnevny!
On what? All I see is a hunk of junk.
I would have thought Sweden's installation on Gotland would impress you more.
Meh. Whatever. It's just a fortress.

Fields.MenuText: Just a fortress? They've got the whole island covered in guns!
It's a pretty strategically important fortress.
Is it because it's Swedish?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, they can congratulate themselves on being the most heavily armed rock in the Baltic.
Until someone comes along with more guns and burns it down. Last I checked, the Morganas had infinite guns.
Why would that matter to me? It's not Soviet, so I don't care about it. It's not a Rusalka, so I can't blow it up, so I don't care about it.
Like it or not, we'll be patrolling in this fortress's shadow. Gotland's a friendly port in unfriendly waters, and it's critical to our force projection.
All right, then. Think of it as drawing enemy fire while you close in for the kill.
@BATTLE
For as long as someone can't just knock it over.
As if! Have I ever told you about Comrade Aurora?
"She's a Belle." That doesn't even begin to cover it. She's only the one who knocked on the doors of the Winter Palace with a six-inch steel fist!
She's a Belle too, isn't she?
You're a real pessimist, you know that?
When I think of how those Provisional Government bureaucrats must have quaked in their boots... Oh, it always gets me buzzing! Take that, Kerensky!
A real shot heard round the world, eh?
Ahem. But that's why your static defenses don't impress me. It only takes a big enough gun to blow them down. That's why you need us Belles to take the fight to the Rusalki.
Hmm... like wounding an enemy and then shooting his friends who come to help him?
If that's how you want to think of it. You know, I bet that sailor you let fire your mine gun would be great at that.
Hmph. He was all right, I suppose.
More than all right, to hear him talk about it. He wouldn't shut up during breakfast about how he beat you at target practice.
Grr. I'll show him target practice.
*ALARM*
Here's your chance. Eyes up.
Grr...
Chert.
Dutiful as ever.
Of course I am! You humans would be drowning in Rusalki without me around.
And seals, by the look of it. Catch any?
Nearly one.

Fields.MenuText: Nearly one?
Keep at it. Maybe you'll get one eventually.
We're provisioned pretty well, but I appreciate your initiative.

Fields.DialogueText: It'll stay that way if you keep distracting me.
Hmph. You'd think blobs with faces would be easier to hit.
Are you patronizing me, Kapitan? Draw my ire and you draw my fire.
If you're bored, you might help the crew with maintenance--
@BATTLE
*SPLASH*
*SPLASH*
Double chert!
Don't want to. They keep me running all right, but I'd probably just get frustrated and start bashing heads.
I could use some company while I work on the last after action report.
Even more boring.
... Or you could depopulate the Baltic until something interesting happens.
Oh, could I, Kapitan? You'd really let me?
*ALARM*
It's your ammunition.
It's not fair! I'm the pride of the Baltic Fleet. Why do they have us guarding some glorified rock?
That's why. The Morganas are making yet another pass.
Where? I don't see any. Just a bunch of ugly, low-hanging clouds.
Those clouds are the Morganas. There, on the horizon.
... Ochevidno. I just wanted to see if you knew.
I didn't say you couldn't.
... Khorosho. If you know what's good for you, you won't.
I take your meaning, though. Our picket ships report heavy Morgana presence on the other side of the peninsula.
Just where the island's thinnest. They're daring us to fire, Kapitan. I don't appreciate being dared.
Podozhdite! There's one now!

Fields.MenuText: Maybe by the way it sat there without moving?
With friends like you, Gotland doesn't need enemies.
That doesn't matter. You fired on incomplete intelligence.

Fields.DialogueText: Look around you, Kapitan! It could have been anything in this fog!
At least you recognize my unrivaled firepower.
Don't insult my intelligence! Sometimes you've got to make split decisions when no one else will.
Besides, it was in my way. If it wasn't a Rusalka it might have been a rock. You should be thanking me for clearing our firing line.
Ugh. I just can't get a clear shot in all this fog.
Visibility problems?
I can see just fine, Kapitan!
We don't want to risk hitting anything friendly. We've got to get into position to flush them out.
That could take forever! Why can't we just blast them here and now?
Gnevny, if we haven't yet ranged them, we might--
*BOOM*
... Get in even deeper trouble.
@BATTLE
Eh... heh heh. Whoops.
Explain. Now.
It's not my fault! The Rusalki could have been anywhere. How was I supposed to know it was a Swedish emplacement?
We'll deal with this later. If you'll excuse me, I have to go avert war with Sweden.
Oh, lighten up! They'll see the funny side in time.
Gnevny? I know you're down here.
Go away.
Hiding from the problem isn't going to solve it. Especially not when you're the one who caused it.
What problem? There were Morganas in Gotland's southern waters. Now they're gone.
Prime Minister Hansson can go jump in a lake. I've heard he doesn't even talk to Communists, so I'm not talking to him.

Fields.MenuText: This isn't going to go away just because you refuse to acknowledge it.
Every time I think we have you straightened out, something comes up.
At least you're not smoking down here.

Fields.DialogueText: But it might. And I am acknowledging it! That's why I'm down here.
Shut up, Kapitan. You are lucky to have me here and you know it!
Because I'm out of cigarettes again. Thanks for the salt. That wound needed packing.
I'm over here, you know.
... Of course you are! I was deliberately avoiding looking at you.
Along with a critical Swedish emplacement. They're damn lucky nobody was killed. But Prime Minister Hansson's calling for a full inquiry.
So I've noticed. It makes me wonder...
Me too. It's a wonder you don't dry up and turn to dust without some hot blood in your veins. You need to stand up to those ungrateful Swedes.
I don't think "we're all you've got, so deal with it" is the Fleet's official stance. It's like you said: you're not the one talking to Sweden. Your actions reflect on the Fleet.
So what do you want me to do, Kapitan?
*ALARM*
Your job, for now. Just brace yourself. It's as much cleaning up as it is making a mess.
Oh, I'll show you a mess...
@BATTLE
Gnevny, you're not being grounded.
What do you call those orders from Command, then? Staying within fifty miles of Gotland seems pretty grounded to me!
It's just until they can clear the road to Burgsvik and the rest of the southern localities. You really did a number on their infrastructure.
Hmph. Glupyye shvedy. It's their fault for letting the Rusalki so close to their island in the first place.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe it's a good thing you don't talk to Swedish press.
You should look at it from their point of view.
What if you'd hurt someone?

Fields.DialogueText: If a mosquito happens to land on your face, I'm doing you a favor by slapping it. It really is that simple.
I would, but I don't like fermented herring.
It's war. You'll shrivel up if you cry over every scrape and bruise.
Don't worry, Gnevny. You're not out of the fight just because you're restricted to Gutnish waters. Quite the opposite, in fact.
I don't see how. Smaller patrol range, fewer fights.
You really need to read the news. Gotland's been under near-constant siege from the beginning.
The Rusalki care about it that much?
It's right in the middle of the Baltic. Control the island and you control the sea. Ever play chess?
A little. I'm good enough to beat my little sister Boiky, and that's enough for me. But I take your meaning.
Here's the deal. You've got the stamina and the firepower. I'll make sure you're everywhere at once. But you have to fire where you're told. No collateral damage.
Hmm... Everywhere at once, you say?
Like God's own flyswatter.
Ha! You've got yourself a deal, Kapitan. Sweden wants a guard dog, eh? I'll keep them up all night with my barking!
Don't make them regret it.
That's their business. I'm to stay out of it, remember?
*ALARM*
Bystro, Kapitan! Today is the first hunt of the rest of your life!
Make it a long one.
@BATTLE
Who's buttering anyone up?
Come, now. There's propaganda posters plastered all over my structure. I'm not one of those American girls who needs patriotism and whiskey to function.
Just violence and vodka.

Fields.MenuText: Want them to be standardized?

Fields.DialogueText: Just make them all bigger, why don't you?
Interesting...
Your cryptic antics perplex and bore me. Find me something to shoot.
Nikogda bol'she. Cheating bastard.
He wears glasses, you know. I'd feed them to him if he weren't so useful. A fair fight is skill against skill alone, no matter how you're built.
*ALARM*
If you're trying to butter me up, Kapitan, it's not going to work.
Ignoring that. And the typefaces are all out of whack! Some of them are massive and some are so small a mouse couldn't read them.

Fields.MenuText: Were they any easier to read up close?
What about the pictures?

Fields.DialogueText: Every single one. Why would that matter?
Blobs of color past a certain distance. Really, Kapitan, you might as well just have the crew splash paint around. I'd at least have the pleasure of slapping them.
You don't want to go shooting with Ensign Palmgren?
Uh-oh. He got one over on you?
Now point me in the direction of some Rusalki like you promised!
You've got it. I think I've learned a lot today.
Not so much that I can't teach you more. Watch and learn!
@BATTLE
Break time?
Even I was surprised. The thing about being always on the hunt is that you run out of things to do.
Some of the crew were just telling me about that. You really have been everywhere at once. Down in the engine room, cleaning your guns...
I blame you, Kapitan. Promise a girl nonstop action and she gets restive when there isn't any.
And yet I always see you reading the same book.
Scarlet Sails is the greatest. That's not my fault. Why settle for less?

Fields.MenuText: Work hard, play hard. Looks like I'm finally rubbing off on you.
There's a whole world of other books out there.
What's so great about it?

Fields.DialogueText: Please, Kapitan, you are an excellent role model! I want to be just as grumpy when I am your age.
And only one is perfect. Everyone has a different one.
It's a fairy tale... and yet not. Nothing wrong with a happy ending that doesn't take magic to happen.
So what's it about?
Is that what you want? To be saved?
@BATTLE
There's this girl who's shunned and misunderstood by her whole village. But she always believes there's something better out there for her, and one day that something comes along.
It'll be a cold day in hell before I need anyone to save me. It's about believing someone will recognize you for who you are and like what they see. About never knuckling under and conforming...
I'm starting to see the appeal.
I knew you would. You're an understanding sort, even if you can be a worrywart. That's what I--
*ALARM*
... And then reveling in the dumbfounded looks when you leave all those chumps in the dust.
Chert! Those damned Rusalki will make me lose my place!
Haven't you memorized it by now?
Principles, Kapitan. It's what separates us from them.
How are the Swedes' repairs coming?
Pozhaluysta, Kapitan. Even the tiniest nugget of information would be better than nothing.

Fields.MenuText: When we sail around the southern part of the island, you'll see it for yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: I guess that's something to look forward to. I'll endure it gracefully.
I'm glad you're keeping busy in in the meantime, at least.
There's something to be said for working among the crew.
There's a sense of togetherness you really only get from being part of one.
I suppose. It's nothing compared to being a vessel of the Baltic Fleet, of course.
Of course.
Of course, of course. Don't be too agreeable, Kapitan. I need someone to argue with between fights.
*ALARM*
You just got your wish. You really enjoy arguing?
It's nothing personal, Kapitan. I can't be the greatest and strongest if I'm not being tested.
@BATTLE
No more quickly than the last few times you asked that this week.

Fields.MenuText: I've got other things on my mind, Gnevny. It's a jungle out here.
I thought you were excited to keep these waters clear.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm going to go solve this mystery on my own if you don't render assistance.
I'll be more excited once I can break this damn leash. I swear I recognize this stretch of ocean.
How, exactly?
We'll both find out. I don't care how I do it as long as I get what I want.
Watching the rebuild?
It's interesting, I suppose.
It doesn't have to be interesting. It just has to work.
I'm still skeptical of your static defenses. But if you're going to shackle yourself to a rock, I wish you'd at least talk to an expert.

Fields.MenuText: You've certainly proven adept at destroying it.

Fields.DialogueText: Proving my point once again. Truth is painful.
I'm a ship, Kapitan. What's more, I'm a vessel of the Baltic Fleet. Shelling these positions is in my blood.
And part of knowing how to destroy something is knowing where to aim.
And part of knowing where to aim is knowing why to aim there.
Can't argue with that. Would you like to borrow my binoculars? You might be able to see better.
I can see just fine, Kapitan.
I don't doubt it. But you might see even better with these.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What do you know about static defenses?
You really think they'd trust you with the rebuild?

Fields.DialogueText: Do you even listen to yourself? You may as well ask a hammer what it knows about nails.
Nyet. But you humans are persistent. They'd come around eventually.
... Vozmozhno. Give them here.
How's it look?
Hmm. I can practically see their silly expressions. These are powerful, I'll give you that.
Ought to help you see exactly what they could be doing better.
*ALARM*
Diving for cover, for one thing! I am not giving the Rusalki the satisfaction of... I mean, not letting them blow this place up.
Whatever keeps it standing, I suppose.
This is new.
You know, many of them had never seen a ship before joining the navy. They have no idea how ships work, and still think they know better than myself how to command them.
And what do you think?
I think my officers are a mix of political appointees and their incompetent cronies. My crew are hard workers, but they can be such superstitious buffoons.
I'm sure you've told them you think that, haven't you?
Not recently, or even that many times!

Fields.MenuText: You know, they might respect you more if you showed them respect.
I wonder what they think about it.
Everyone comes from somewhere. What matters is working with them here.

Fields.DialogueText: We've been making progress. They acquit themselves well, mostly. But I won't hesitate to fight when they don't.
Sometimes I do too. A little vodka usually puts out that fire.
I am learning to work with them, but they need to learn that they need to work with me!
But I'm finding my urge to destroy them flaring up less and less lately.
That's good.
What, me being creative?
I usually see you shooting or reading.
Ought to give the sailors something to talk about.
I imagine by now they've all got stories about making you angry and surviving.
It's in the name. Sit with me.
I guess I've got time.
It's terrible! Sometimes I go for hours without wanting to punch someone. Am I going soft, Kapitan?
Your drawings tell me you're just finding another outlet.
Aren't these diagrams great?
I'll have to look them over another time. I notice you've provided helpful illustrations... of yourself shelling it.
I got bored.
Uh-huh. Certainly explains the Swedes running in terror. And that's a very... idealized self-portrait.
You... you really like it?
What I meant was--
I mean, of course you like it! I made it.
*ALARM*
Just you wait, Kapitan! There's more where this came from.
@BATTLE
Posters again, Kapitan?
Are you calling me drab?

Fields.MenuText: I'm about to call for reinforcements.
Of course not. A little inspiration now and then does wonders for the war effort.
Let's just say you're lucky you picked me as your captain.

Fields.DialogueText: Good instinct, Kapitan. Only someone exceptionally brave or foolish would dare face me alone.
Not all of the sailors are good Communists, but nobody's perfect.
Hmph. I'd like to see you pull off my style.
Besides, if you were drab, it'd be our fault for having built you that way.
Like I say, Kapitan. I make the best of what I'm given.
Speaking of... you've yet to return my binoculars.
Thought the place could use some sprucing up.
Ah! You're correct, Kapitan. I have, shall we say, appropriated them.
Stolen.
Don't be so defensive, Kapitan. I know when you're trying to send me a message.
You'd been complaining so much about your eyesight. I thought I'd at least help without trying to imply... that you needed any.
You said it yourself. If I'm a certain way, it's because you built me that way. Blame the Zhdanov shipyards for my eyesight.
First step to solving a problem is--
*ALARM*
Spotting rounds?
Can't fire for effect without them.
@BATTLE
I suppose so. Just so we can get this out of the way discreetly.
Will you tell me how far away you have to stand to read the posters, at least?
And... that ought to do it. Would you like to see my plans for the new emplacement?
Not all of it. I used some of it to roll cigarettes.
You're paying for the next resupply.
Planned for that too. I save for incidentals like that. Look!

Fields.MenuText: Looks unassailable.
I notice your... artistic liberties are missing from this draft.
Fine line work, Gnevny. I didn't know you had it in you.

Fields.DialogueText: It ought to be! I simply asked myself what would be most frustrating to shell.
My picture was on the front page of every newspaper in Sweden for a glorious week. They already know what I look like.
I can be patient when I want to be, Kapitan.
Now, in a perfect world most of this would be underground. Earth doesn't shatter the way walls tend to. But coastal bunkers obviously have problems with that.
You know what really brought the Provisional Government down? Too damn many windows, that's what I say.
You realize they've already embarked on the rebuild.
I'd wondered where all the graph paper went.
Hence the thickness of the walls.
K sozhaleniyu. But I figured they would value my input. At the very least, the Belle responsible for such a mess should give some thought to cleaning it up and preventing future messes like it.
I really can't argue with that. I'm glad you did this.
Spasibo, Kapitan.
Of course, Gnevny. You're making amends for a mistake. As your captain it's my responsibility to help you.
You'll... you'll show them, won't you? What I did?
It means a lot to me.
*ALARM*
Slava Bogu. I almost...
Almost what?
Nothing, Kapitan! Never mind my eyes. You need to check your ears.
@BATTLE
Who are these men aboard me, Kapitan?
And the Red Fleet agreed!?
After some grumbling, but yes. They've got bigger fish to fry than trying to save face over your actions.
Well, they can forget about talking to me!
Why would I trust them? I blew up their fortress! Would you trust someone who blew up your fortress?

Fields.MenuText: If anyone blew you up, I'd hunt them to the ends of the earth.
Only after they made amends and promised to do better.
Depends on the someone.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh! I... Spasibo. Ah... I'd expect nothing less, Kapitan! You are mine, after all.
You're too trusting, Kapitan. Don't let it get us blown up.
I'm in no mood for flattery, Kapitan, and that is saying something.
You don't have to make them dinner or anything. Just be polite, answer their questions, and make it clear you're on their side.
But I'm--
The Swedish Engineer Troops sent some observers. The Prime Minister insisted.
You don't trust them?
You're what?
Grr. Fine. I get it. I've done enough damage. But they started it. This is me burying the hatchet, as the Americans say.
There's a first time for everything.
Hey! I can be charitable when I want to be. I might even offer them some of my cigarettes.
I'm sure they'll appreciate the grid square pattern.
Touché.
*ALARM*
Prevoskhodno! Time to show those discount Vikings just whose side I'm really on.
@BATTLE
V zaklyucheniye. I'm glad that's over.
You did well. I think you made a great impression on them.
Well, listen closer. I think this calls for a celebration. I'm making you dinner.
Dinner?
Da. And you're not allowed to refuse. I threw you through all kinds of hoops this tour. You're the last one I haven't made amends with.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't know you could cook.
I think that's a wonderful idea. Those engineers just missed something great.
I'm glad you're coming to terms with your role in all this.

Fields.DialogueText: War isn't all I'm good at. I'll have you know I make a mean borscht.
Let them have their surströmming, or whatever it is Swedes eat.
Oh, don't spoil it, Kapitan. My heart was in the right place, even if my shells might not have been.
Perfect. It's a date.
Otlichno! Of course it's a da... ack!
Are you all right, Gnevny?
Something dear to you?
And they on me. Those Swedes are professionals, I'll give them that. I don't know how I'd react if I came face to face with anyone who blew up someone dear to me.
Always.
That's what I said. Are you listening?
Uh... Duck! Maybe I'll cook us a duck. A whole flock!
It's just an expression.
*ALARM*
Can't hear you! Rusalki inbound!
@BATTLE
Hm hmm hmm hm hmmm hmm... Kapitan! What's that!?
There, in your hand!
A sandwich?
Why aren't you fasting!?
You've got to be good and hungry for the dinner I'm making you. You're going to spoil your appetite otherwise, and all the work I put in will have been wasted.

Fields.MenuText: There's always room for what you make, Gnevny.
I barely ate this morning. I worked straight through breakfast.
Had we even decided on a date yet?

Fields.DialogueText: You're making me blush, Kapitan.
See? You were doing so well!
Soon. I don't know. Stop using that word. It throws me off balance.
Don't worry, Gnevny. The Morganas have been out in force lately. We've all got to keep our strength up.
Not that you'd let that stop you.
Admit it. You like that about me.
What's what?
Why the hell would I be fasting?
I figured that might happen.
With annoyance!
Hmph. As long as it's for the war's sake, I suppose I can't complain.
I can't deny a certain charm.
Ha! I win.
Asking someone on a date isn't a competition, you know.
Shut up! I'm just repaying you.
*ALARM*
Well, get used to it. I've got a gift for you.
Grr... You pick now of all times to tell me!? Once we're done with these Rusalki, you're next!
@BATTLE
*SPLASH*
How's the hunt?
Frustrating but worthwhile.
Why would I be looking for ducks? You're getting narwhal for dinner and you're going to like it.

Fields.MenuText: I don't eat meat. I don't know if I'd told you.
What if I don't?
I've always thought they were too cute to eat.

Fields.DialogueText: Fine. I'm getting narwhal. Not like a salad's particularly hard to hunt.
Nevozmozhno. I'm the best cook in my class. Ask any of my sisters.
Tell that to a halibut.
There's nothing quite like a home-cooked meal.
Do you consider me your home, Kapitan?
Grr! I'll get you, you obese unicorn!
I appreciate the effort, but I don't think you'll find any ducks out here.
My home away from home. The crew do, too.
Don't listen to them. They think I'm going soft.
Your results in battle say otherwise.
Good. You're focusing on the right thing.
Tishe! Someone will hear.
I don't think there's anything wrong with doing something nice for someone. That's what I'm trying to do with your glas--
Who? We're alone out here.
*ALARM*
See? The Rusalki are listening for my every weakness.
Fine. You win.
I always win, Kapitan. Eventually.
@BATTLE
Well?
Come on, Kapitan! You're stalling.
I had food in my mouth. It's rude to talk with food in your mouth.
You say rude. I say economical.
I say this is delicious.
Really!? Heh... Well, of course you do. I put a lot of work into it.

Fields.MenuText: I told you they'd do you some good.
They look pretty good on you, too.
Lots of people are nearsighted. No reason to be ashamed.

Fields.DialogueText: I haven't even used them in battle yet. Don't be presumptuous.
Of course they do! I can make anything look good.
Not everyone's built that way.
You don't have to wear them all the time. But I think they might help when visibility's poor. In the fog, among the engines, at night...
You don't have to. Your expression says it all.
Interrupt my dinner, will they? Prepare to die, Rusalki!
@BATTLE
I can tell. I put a fair amount of effort into this, too. Here.
Kapitan?
I hope so. Well, how are they?
Everything's so... crisp.
I see.
I took notes on what you told me about reading those posters. Command got me in contact with an eye doctor to translate them into a prescription.
I... don't really know what to say. I feel... this is...
*ALARM*
H-hey! Don't act like you know what goes on in my head.
Can I come in?
I was just being polite. You're a guest aboard me, you know.

Fields.MenuText: That's not exactly what politeness means.

Fields.DialogueText: There's a learning curve, Kapitan. You should be more patient.
I'm glad you liked your dinner. I really wanted to do my best for you. But I think when you gave me my glasses I maybe... kind of, sort of...
What was that? You said that last bit really quietly.
I'm sorry, okay? You went to all kinds of trouble to do something nice for me, and I didn't even say thank you.
You're not used to it. But I could tell it meant a lot to you.
What the hell do you mean, not used to... ugh. No. You're right.
Heh. I think this whole Gotland stint really has softened me up. But I wanted to thank you properly.
You're already here, Gnevny. But... yes.

Fields.MenuText: An honored guest?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't get cute, Kapitan. I don't know how to deal with it.

Fields.MenuText: And don't I know it.

Fields.DialogueText: That's right! Now, as I was saying...
I never thought you were underperforming. You make the very best of what you were built with.
Da. I'm not stupid, Kapitan. Boiky complains all the time about her equipment. I don't believe for a minute that we're everything the Red Navy wanted.
But you're what they got, and damn it, they're going to miss you when you're gone.
Maybe you really do know what's in my head.
Well, as long as we're making confessions, the truth is--
*ALARM*
What? We can walk and talk.
Later, Kapitan. I'm not ready.
@BATTLE
I thought I'd find you here.
Flexing your incredible mind powers again?
I just followed the ashes. It's been a long time since you smoked down here.
It's not like I'm a stranger to putting things at risk.
I knew it wasn't a Rusalka.

Fields.MenuText: You don't have to say that just because you feel bad.
And you fired on it anyway?
Have you told anyone else about this?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I'm either ignorant or malicious, and you know damn well I'm not ignorant.
You don't need to rub it in, Kapitan. I've been doing that enough on my own.
Of course not! It took me this long to even decide I shouldn't have done it.
It was in my way. I knew there were Rusalki on the other side, and I wanted a clear shot. That's it.
Why do I do anything, Kapitan? Because it's convenient! Because I can't let anything slow me down! Because the minute someone picks up my slack, the Red Navy may just hang me with it!
At least... that's the way it was at first. And then things slowed down, and when you have more time to look at the things you once saw as distractions, as obstacles, it... you...
Credit where it's due. You're usually so careful down--
What?
That Swedish fortification. It wasn't a rock, either. It was blurry, but I know rocks don't have embrasures.
Why didn't you tell me?
You must think I'm horrible, Kapitan. And that's started mattering to me more. And I can't decide whether that's worse than not caring at all.
What did I say the first step to solving a problem was?
I didn't let you finish.
Well, I'd say you took it. And if you can take one, you can take the next, and the one after that. You're Gnevny. You don't let anything stop you. You're not going to stop now.
*ALARM*
I guess not. Thanks, Kapitan.
Wish these Morganas would give us some space.
We'll make some. I'd say I'm pretty good at that.
@BATTLE
Take a good look, Gnevny. We're leaving Gotland behind.
I've never liked the Gulf of Bothnia.
Too cold?
Too vexing. It could be ours if those cheating Finns weren't in the way.
You're a credit to the Baltic Fleet, Gnevny. But the international fleet is lucky to have you, too. You've got a whole world to protect. And yes, that includes Scandinavia.
Despite my efforts to the contrary.

Fields.MenuText: Nothing is going to come of beating yourself up.
You think you're the first person to make a bad choice?
Gotland seems to think otherwise these days.

Fields.DialogueText: Except perhaps spiting the Zhdanov boys.
I'm probably the first ship to make this particular bad choice.
Well, to hell with what they think. I'm right, they're wrong. So there.
Whether you like it or not, Sweden appreciates what you've done to make things right. You might even be a hero once all's said and done. And that's something you're going to have to live with.
It's all you. That's what I like about it.
Kapitan...
It wouldn't be the first thing I've learned to live with, would it?
I really appreciate you, Kapitan. I'm not good at saying these things. And that's something I can't blame on the Zhdanov shipyards.
It probably won't be the last. But if there's any way I can help... please don't hesitate to let me know.
And it's something I'd certainly like to help with.
You know, my eyesight's fine up close. I can see you perfectly. Maybe... maybe more clearly than--
*ALARM*
We'll pick this up later?
If I have to do it at the bottom of the sea.
@BATTLE
You know, I haven't seen you wearing your glasses in battle.
Just because you don't see something doesn't mean it isn't there. I should know.
So where are they?
I stole a soldering iron from one of the mechanics. Vot.
Iron sights, eh?
Iron and glass.

Fields.MenuText: Does it work?
The Morganas won't see us coming. But you will.
You always were good at blending form and function.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not blind at range, Kapitan, but accuracy helps.
I wish I could have seen that coming. Well, maybe not.
Bet you never thought you'd say that to a knockoff Folgore-class, eh?
I'm glad I could help.
It's a different way of looking at the world, Kapitan.
A better way?
I'll have to live it for a while to pass judgment. But so far... I kind of like it.
Amazing what a new perspective will teach you.
Whether you want it to or not, at first.
Sometimes you need a little push to get there.
Or an explosion?
Or that. Let's keep those under control, shall we?
Listen to you. It's like you don't even know me.
Then teach me. How do you feel right now?
Read Scarlet Sails sometime. You'll understand.
*ALARM*
Right before a battle, with a kapitan I have confessed my feelings to? Hmm...
Alexander Grin described this feeling as like a beehive and a garden in one's mouth. That's how I feel.
I like it. I don't know what it means, though.
